note.p: Daniel Price Porter was an attorney and politician in Mississippi in the nineteenth century. Born in 1835 in Hinds County, Mississippi, Porter began practicing law in Jackson, Mississippi, around 1859. In 1863, in the midst of the Civil War, Porter became Secretary of the Mississippi Senate and served in that role until 1875. Three years later, On September 25, 1878, Porter received an appointment to be Mississippi’s interim Secretary of State, following the death of Secretary Kinloch Falconer. He held the position until November 15, 1878, when Henry C. Myers formally assumed the office. Porter remained in the Mississippi government, serving as Deputy Secretary of State for several more years. From 1893 to 1894, he served as postmaster in Jackson. Porter died on June 24, 1899. He was married to Catherine Patton Hobson and had six children. Porter is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
Daniel Price Porter belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Prentiss County, Marietta was founded in the 1800s. (Wikipedia)
Located in northeast Mississippi, Itawamba County was established on March 1, 1836 from Monroe County. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in northeast Mississippi, Tishomingo County was established on February 9, 1836. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: The Confederate Army was the military land force of the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Known also as the Confederate States Army or Southern Army, it was established by the Provisional Confederate Congress in February 1861 and fell under the authority of Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Modeled after the U.S. Army of the 19th century, the Confederate Army technically fell into two categories: a small regular army of professional officers and soldiers (the Army of the Confederate States of America) and a much larger, temporary force of citizen soldiers intended to exist only for the duration of the war (the Provisional Army of the Confederate States). In reality, the Confederacy’s regular army never fully developed and the overwhelming majority of Confederate soldiers served in the provisional force. The distinction between the two played little role during military operations and all were generally considered to be part of the overall Confederate Army.

As many as 1,000,000 soldiers served in the Confederate Army between 1861 and 1865, although not all at one time. Most were volunteers, however, the Confederate government instituted a conscription (or draft) in April 1862—the first in U.S. or Confederate history—to increase the size of the Confederacy’s military force and encourage voluntary enlistment. The government passed two more conscription acts over the next two years. More than ten percent of the men who served in Confederate ranks were drafted.

Over ninety percent of soldiers in the Confederate Army were native-born white men. Nine percent were foreign-born white men. Several Native American units—particularly from the Cherokee, Creek, and Choctaw tribes—served within the Confederate military, especially in the trans-Mississippi theatre. The Confederate military heavily relied upon the forced labor of enslaved African Americans for building fortifications and carrying out menial tasks, and the Confederate government did not formally allow African Americans (free or slave) to join the army until a last minute desperate measure passed the Confederate Congress in March 1865, only weeks before the end of the war. Only around two hundred enslaved soldiers were organized into service, but they were not sent into combat.

By the time the last Confederate soldiers surrendered to Union forces in June 1865, nearly 100,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 160,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America. Army. Mississippi. Infantry Regiment, 26th
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: The 26th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized in summer 1861 in Tishomingo County, Mississippi under the command of Col. Arthur E. Reynolds and served in the Trans-Mississippi Theater General under Tilghman's and Adams' Brigades in the Department of Mississippi and East Louisiana. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 25; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 502-507; National Park Service-Battle Units)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America. Army. Mississippi. Infantry Regiment, 26th. Company G
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: Commonly known as the Marietta Rifles, Company G of the 26th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized on August 16, 1861 in Tishomingo County, Mississippi under the command of Capt. Tully F. Parker and served in the Trans-Mississippi Theater. It was later commanded by Capt. Albert E. Earley. (Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 504; Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 25)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies." (Cambridge Dictionary)

element.label: Creator
element.value: Parker, Tully F.; Porter, D. P.; Price, R.

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Pettus Collection. List from Captain Tully F. Parker at Marietta, Itawamba County (now Prentiss County), Mississippi, listing the men in the "Marietta Rifles" (Company G, 26th Mississippi Infantry) under his command who have or have not performed nine days of drill. Parker's list is witnessed by and sworn before R. Price, justice of the peace for Tishomingo County, Mississippi. In a note on the reverse dated June 29, 1861, Adjutant General Pro Tem D. P. Porter acknowledges receipt of the list.

div.p: Marietta Riflesat Marietta Itawamba County Miss. have performed Nine days Drill at their drill Ground the following is a Correct List of the Nams under Capt. T. F. Parker

div.note: NOTE: In 1861, Marietta MS was located in Itawamba County; in 1870, Prentiss County was formed from Itawamba and Tishomingo Counties. As of 1870 Marietta has been in Prentiss County.
